name: How do I edit my Leadin Popup Form?
post_body:
1. Navigate to Settings > Popup Form
  2. Change 'Show the popup on' to either 'All pages' or 'Only the following templates' (if you are using WordPress) or 'Only pages with a URL containing' (if you are using the Leadin Web App).
  3. Click Save Settings at the bottom of the page

Under the popup form options, you can configure almost every aspect of your popup form.

Popup targeting 

From here you can configure your Leadin Popup Form to appear on no pages (disabling the popup), all pages or on pages with a URL containing certain text. In this example the popup form will appear on any page where the URL contains '/blog' or '/products'. This would include 'website.com/blog/my-blog-post' and and 'website.com/products/product-number-one' but would not include 'website.com/contact'. If you are using the Leadin WordPress plugin, this option will be replaced with the option to target certain page templates provided by your WordPress Theme.

Popup triggers

This setting allows you to choose what user interaction will trigger the popup form. Page scroll will trigger the moment your visitor scrolls 50% down your page. Elapsed time simply triggers the moment X seconds have past. Exit intent allows you to trigger the popup form when the visitor's mouse exits the their browser window (for example, when they're about to close the browser tab). Exit intent can be very effective when paired with the 'Page overlay' popup location.

Popup location & language

Next up, we can change the location of our popup to appear in four different positions, bottom right, bottom left, top banner and page overlay. Each has their own advantages depending on what you're using your Leadin Popup Form to achieve. We recommend experimenting with different locations to see which works best for you. 

Popup language allows you to change the language of the non-editable parts of the popup, including the form field labels. Currently it is possible to translate these parts of the form to French, Spanish, Japanese, German and Brazilian Portuguese. Looking for a language that's not listed? Let us know.

Popup content

The meat and bones of your popup form. This section allows you to edit the header, description, image and button text, along with adding a customized thank you message that your contacts will see when they submit the form. Try adding a secondary call-to-action like following your company on twitter! 

Popup colors

By default Leadin will include 6 standard colors, but why not set a custom color that matches your brand? When you install Leadin it will scan your homepage for the 6 most dominant colors on your site for you to chose from. You'll find these listed under 'Colors from your site'.

Other options

Some additional settings include the ability to set a Redirect URL, include fields for first/last name and phone number, disable or enable the popup form for those visiting your website on a mobile device and preview functionality. If you set a Redirect URL Leadin will automatically open this URL in a new tab in the contact's browser as soon as they submit the form. 

IMPORTANT: The popup preview option will open a new tab in your browser and display the Leadin Popup Form immediately, with any changes you have made. This preview will not wait for the triggers you have set, it will display the popup form straight away so you can confirm any changes you've made. Be sure to come back and click Save Settings when you're done.

Here's how the popup form looks, as an example:

  1. Navigate to Settings > Popup Form
  2. Change 'Show the popup on' to No pages
  3. Click Save Settings at the bottom of the page
meta_description: Configure your Leadin Popup Form from within Settings > Popup Form

name: How do I merge forms in Leadin?
post_body:
Leadin identifies forms based on the unique CSS selector of the form on your site. You may find that Leadin identifies what it considers to be two unique forms, but to you and your team, they are actually the same form. It is now possible to merge forms together inside Leadin and have both these unique forms on your site become one form in Leadin.

  1. Navigate to the form you wish to merge
  2. Click Merge Form
  3. Choose the form you which to merge this form into
  4. Check the confirmation box to confirm you understand this cannot be reversed
  5. Click Merge

You should now find that the contacts from your initial list have been merged into your chosen form, going forward any news submissions on your old form will be found inside your chosen form.

IMPORTANT: When you merge a form, your contacts will become a member of the form you chose in step 3, along with any future submissions on the original form. In addition, the old form will inherit the settings from your chosen form for your notification email and connected email lists.

name: Your Blog Post Title Here...
How do I use the Collected Forms tool?
post_body:
In addition to lead flows, Leadin's collected forms tool collects submissions on your website's existing forms, making it possible to consolidate all your leads into your Leadin contacts database regardless of which form your visitors submit on your website.

Collected forms is enabled by default in Leadin, meaning you should begin to see leads generated in your account as soon as Leadin is installed. You can manage all your collected forms via 'Collected Forms' in the navigation in Leadin. 

How do I enable or disable collected forms?

Within collected forms in Leadin you should find an on/off switch in the top-right, as shown here:

Once enabled, Leadin will automatically start collecting submissions on your website as soon as submissions occur. When disabled, Leadin will no longer collect submissions on your own website forms, however all your lead flows will continue to generate submissions, as these are separate tools.

What information can I see for a collected form?

Leadin currently provides the following informaiton for each collected form in the sidebar of each form: 

  • URL of the most recent page Leadin collected a submission on
    • If a form exists on multiple pages, Leadin will show the most recent URL here
  • Date Leadin first collected a submission on this form
  • The CSS selector for this form
    • Leadin uniquely identifies each form based on the CSS selector of the form itself. By default the form will be named by it's CSS selector but you can rename the form and find the original selector here

To learn a little more about how this technically works, check out this artice.

What kind of forms can Leadin collect submissions on?

Provided your form is a static HTML form, wrapped in a HTML <form> tag and not contained inside an <iframe>, Leadin should be able to capture the submissions.  

Some common reasons why Leadin would not be able to capture submissions on forms:

  • Form not enclosed in <form> tags
  • Form contained inside an <iframe>
  • Form has JavaScript bound to form submit event or submit button click event
    • This is how Leadin captures submissions, and any other events can prevent Leadin from knowing when submissions occur
  • Form was introduced after the page completed loading
    • Leadin scans the page as soon as it loads and listens to submissions on forms that were present at that point
  • Form contained a sensitive field, such as credit card

Which form builders/plugins can I use with Leadin?

While Leadin can collect submissions on most forms, there are some which Leadin cannot collect submissions on due to the reasons above. Of those that we've tested, below are a list of those that are supported and those that are unsupported. If you do not see your form builder/plugin here, reach out to us and we can confirm if it will or will not work with Leadin.

Supported

Unsupported

  • Contact Form 7
  • JetPack
  • Fast Secure Contact Form
  • Contact Form
  • Gravity Forms
  • Formidable
  • Ninja Forms (< v3.0)
  • Contact Form Clean and Simple
  • Quform
  • Google Forms
  • MailChimp embeddable forms
  • Native WordPress comment forms
  • Most custom forms
  • Wufoo
  • WooCommerce
  • Easy Contact Forms
  • Disqus comments
  • Jetpack comment forms
  • JotForm
  • SumoMe
  • Ninja Popups
  • Ninja Forms (v3.0+)
  • Forms contained in an iFrame
  • Optinmonster
  • FormCraft
  • cVita
  • Typeform
  • Caldera
  • Form Maker
meta_description: As soon as Leadin is installed on your website, it can immediately capture submissions on the existing forms on your website, no additional setup required. Leadin can capture submissions on almost all forms, provided they follow standard HTML form common practices.

name: How do I update my Leadin WordPress plugin?
post_body:
If your Leadin WordPress plugin is out of date, follow these steps to get updated and take advantage of all the newest features and fixes.

  1. Head on over to your WordPress admin and click 'Plugins' in your WordPress side menu.

Some much older versions may not prompt you to update in this way. If you do not see an update available, but you are on an older version of Leadin, check out this article to learn how to install a fresh version of the plugin. You'll need to deactivate and delete the version you're currently using.

name: How do I install Leadin on my WordPress website?
post_body:
In your web browser, navigate to leadin.hubspot.com/get-started. Fill out the form and a download of the Leadin WordPress plugin should automatically begin. If this doesn't happen automatically, choose the "Click here" link to force the download.

Now that you've downloaded the plugin, you'll want to navigate and log into your WordPress admin. Next, go to Plugins > Add New.

From the Add Plugins page, click on Upload Plugin at the top.

Next locate the zip file you downloaded of the Leadin plugin by clicking Choose File.

This will prompt a pop-up box to open where you can search your computer for the file. Once you find the file, click the zip file and then click Open.

Now you'll see the selected file in WordPress. Click the Install Now button to begin installation of Leadin.

Once the install of the Leadin plugin is initiated, you'll be redirected to an install screen that should show you the steps taken to unpack and install the plugin. Once finished, click Activate Plugin to continue.

Now you've successfully installed and activated Leadin! You should see Leadin appear in your side menu in WordPress, click here to get started.
meta_description: In your web browser, navigate to leadin.hubspot.com/get-started. Fill out the form and a download of the Leadin WordPress plugin should automatically begin. If this doesn't happen automatically, choose the "Click here" link to force the download.

name: How do I receive email notifications from Leadin?
post_body:
To enable/edit email notifications for new submissions on your lead flows, click Lead Flows in the navigation and then Settings in the top-right.

From here, you'll find Email Notifications and Email Sync. In Email Notifications you can add, edit and remove any addresses needed.

To enable/edit email notifications for new submissions on your collected forms, click Collected Forms in the navigation and then Settings in the top-right.

From here, you'll find Email Notifications and Email Sync. In Email Notifications you can add, edit and remove any addresses needed.

To disable email notifications, remove all emails from the settings and click Save Changes at the bottom.

Not seeing email notifications from Leadin? Be sure to check your spam folder.

name: How to use Leadin with Fast Secure Contact Form
post_body:
If you are using Fast Secure Contact Form and it's not working with Leadin, it's probably because the "Enable to prevent double click on submit button" option is toggled on in the form settings. Here's what that setting does in Fast Secure Contact Form:

"This setting disables the Submit button after click, to prevent double click on button. Also prevents going back and submit the form again. Note: this setting is ignored if the "Are you sure?" popup for the submit button is enabled, or when you have filled in the Submit button input attributes setting with a "onclick" attribute."

The more geeky explanation is that this option adds an "onclick" Javascript event to the form submission, causing the Fast Secure Contact Form plugin to bypass the existing HTML submission logic and use it's own Javascript code to submit the form. This means Leadin can't hook into the submission event and misses the form submissions.

Luckily there's an easy fix for this which allows Leadin to capture submissions correctly.

Log into your WordPress Dashboard and click Plugins then FS Contact Form.

Choose the form you want to edit from the list of options in the Select a Form drop down.

Click the Advanced tab.

Scroll down to the Advanced Form Settings section and uncheck the Enable to prevent double click on submit button checkbox then click Save Changes.

Leadin should now be able to listen for, and collect submissions on your Fast Secure Contact Form now.
meta_description: If you are using Fast Secure Contact Form and it's not working with Leadin, it's probably because the "Enable to prevent double click on submit button" option is toggled on in the form settings. Here's what that setting does in Fast Secure Contact Form.

name: Why can't I log into Leadin?
post_body:
If you are seeing an error when attempting to log into Leadin, there are a few potential causes depending on the type of account you have.

If you are using the WordPress plugin version of Leadin, then you do not actually have a login for the web portal for Leadin. This is by design. The standalone version of Leadin was built for those using something other than WordPress to build their website. Do not fret, both version are exactly the same, the only difference is that you can manage Leadin right from within the WordPress interface.

If you have previously signed up for a Leadin account (not using the WordPress plugin) and you are having trouble accessing your account, try resetting your password here. If you are still experiencing issues, please let us know.

Since Leadin is built by HubSpot, we share the same infrastructure. This means that, if you use the HubSpot CRM, or Sidekick, or the HubSpot Marketing tool, you will use the same email and password to log into Leadin. If you attempt to log into Leadin using this email and password, but have not signed up for a Leadin account, you will not be able to access Leadin. Please first sign up, and then you will be able to access Leadin.

Let us know.
meta_description: If you are seeing an error when attempting to log into Leadin, there are a few potential causes depending on the type of account you have.

name: The Leadin Weekly Digest email
post_body:
Every Monday, Leadin will send you a digest email outlining your performance for the previous week.

This email includes a bunch of information, breaking down your newly generated contacts day-to-day, and by source, along with highlighting your most engaged contacts new and returning.

Leadin will automatically send this email out to you by default. It is sent to all email addresses listed under Email Notifications in Settings. If you wanted to enable/disable this email, simply check the box Send weekly digest email.

This email will provide you with a breakdown of the new contacts generated last week, broken down by day, and by source. You can use this information to identify which days perform the best, and also, which source channel is your most successful helping you identify which channel is working, and which might need some attention.

On top of this, we include a breakdown of the most engaged contacts, both new contacts and those returning to your website.

name: How does Leadin categorise the source of a contact?
post_body:
Leadin analyses each visit to your website and applies a series of rules to determine the source of the visit. Contact Sources in the Stats of Leadin are categorised based on the source of their first known visit.

There are 6 potential categories used by Leadin (more specific rules can be found below):

  • Direct: Visits to your website with no referring source or tracking URL. Usually visitors who type your website directly into their browser.
  • Email: Visits from tracking links in your emails. These links might be automatically added to the emails you send from providers like MailChimp. They can also be manually added as a tracking URLs.
  • Organic: Non-paid visits from recognised search engines, like Google, Bing, Yahoo, etc.
  • Paid: Visits from paid search ads that are either automatically identified by Leadin or set by tracking URLs.
  • Referrals: Visits from links clicked on other websites.
  • Social: Visits from links clicked on social media sites, like Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, etc.

Leadin uses two methods to identify the source of a visit to your website.

  1. The first is by looking for a tracking URL, which is a parameter that can be added to the end of a link to your website. A tracking URL might look something like this: http://hubspot.com?utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=social&utm_campaign=xyz.
  2. The second is by the “referrer,” which is the information passed along when someone clicks on a link from another website to your website. The referrer is the original site that contained the link to your website. If someone clicks on a link on 'cnn.com' to visit 'http://leadin.com', then the referrer is cnn.com.

When determining the source of a visit, Leadin will honour the tracking URL first. If there is no tracking URL, Leadin will honor the referrer. If there is no tracking URL or referrer, Leadin will categorise the visit into direct traffic.

These rules are listed in order of importance. The first rule that is matched will determine the source of a visit.

Rule Order Rule in Plain EnglishSource
1utm_medium=“social” and utm_source= the name of a social network
utm_medium=" social" and referring domain is a social media site		Social
3utm_source OR utm_medium OR utm_campaign OR source contains the word “email”Email
4utm_source OR utm_medium OR utm_campaign OR source contains the word “adword”, “ppc”, or “cpc”Paid
5gclid= parameter is present (Google click ID)Paid
6utm_source OR utm_medium OR utm_campaign is present and the referring domain is google.comPaid
8Referring domain is a social media siteSocial
9Referring domain is a search engineOrganic
10Referring domain is not a social media site or search engine Referral
11Referring domain is a mail domain or RSS readerDirect

IMPORTANT: these rules are case sensitive and may require lowercase utm parameters to be bucketed correctly.

  • utm_source
  • utm_medium
  • utm_campaign
meta_description: Leadin analyses each visit to your website and applies a series of rules to determine the source of the visit. Contact Sources in the Stats of Leadin are categorised based on the source of their first known visit. There are 6 potential categories used by Leadin.

name: How do I connect Leadin to Constant Contact?
post_body:
Leadin can connect with your Constant Contact account to push contacts who submit your forms into specific lists in Constant Contact.

  1. Navigate to Settings, in Leadin
  2. Select Constant Contact as your Email Provider under Email Sync.
  3. Click Connect to Constant Contact.

Log into Constant Contact and follow the prompts.

Once you have Leadin and Constant Contact connected, next up you can select which forms push to which Constant Contact lists.

  1. Navigate to Collected Forms, in Leadin.
  2. Select the form you would like to push to Constant Contact.
  3. Click Actions and Edit Constant Contact lists.
  4. Check the Constant Contact list(s) you would like to push contacts into.
  5. Click Save.
  6. You should be all set. Leadin will successfully push to the selected Constant Contact lists for future contacts.
  7. For Lead Flows you can find the same option under the Options tab of the editor.

The above GIF shows a MailChimp example, it is the same process for all email providers.

Leadin will automatically push new contacts who submit your form to your chosen Constant Contact lists however it is important to note that Leadin will not retroactively push contacts who submitted your form before configuring these steps, only new contacts going forward.

name: Why are my Contacts not pushing to MailChimp?
post_body:
If you have configured Leadin to push Contacts into your MailChimp lists and your contacts are not making it into MailChimp successfully, below are some errors you might be seeing and what they mean.

If your new contacts are not pushing to MailChimp, you can find out what the most recent error was by navigating to Settings where you wil see the most recent error listed under Email Sync.

From within Leadin settings you will see:

  1. The most recent error, as reported by MailChimp.
  2. A button to dismiss this error once it has been resolved.

Some common errors:

  • FNAME must be provided - Please enter a value
  • LNAME must be provided - Please enter a value
  • MMERGE2 must be provided - Please enter a value
  • MMERGE(x) must be provided - Please enter a value

These errors are occurring because the MailChimp list has required Merge Tags which Leadin does not send over a value for.

Leadin will always push email address to MailChimp, since we know the email address for a contact. If your forms include a first and last name field Leadin should capture this information too and send it to MailChimp.

Head on over to MailChimp and find the List that Leadin is pushing to. Go to Settings > List fields and *|MERGE|* tags and you should see something like this:

  1. The 'Put this tag in your content:' column will correspond with the error reported in Leadin.
  2. The 'Required?' column will need to be unchecked in order for Leadin to be able to successfully push to this list.
meta_description: If you have configured Leadin to push Contacts into your MailChimp lists and your contacts are not making it into MailChimp successfully, these are some errors you might be seeing and what they mean.

name: How does Leadin capture form submissions?
post_body:
Leadin has the ability to capture form submissions, not only on your Leadin popup form, but on most existing forms on your website too. Check out this article for more information the type of forms that Leadin can capture.

Leadin listens for a submission on a form on your website, which we identify by the HTML <form> tag. As we detect a submission (we bind to the form submission event) we gather the information on the form and capture it in a cookie.

As soon as a submission has occurred, Leadin stores the submission information in a cookie on the visitors browser. This cookie is called li_formsub. The purpose of this cookie is to ensure that Leadin can process the submission, even if the form redirects to a new page.

In the event that the page redirects, once the contact loads a new page on your site Leadin will see the previously set li_formsub cookie and capture the information, removing the cookie in the process.

In the event that the page does not redirect, Leadin will wait a brief moment and then capture the data stored in the li_formsub cookie and remove the cookie.

Once Leadin captures the form submission from cookie it is processed by Leadin, generating a submission notification email (if it is enabled) and pushing your contact to any connected email provider lists (such as MailChimp). This process can take approximately two minutes.

name: Why do I not see my forms in Leadin?
post_body:
Forms in Leadin are based on the forms on your website. This means that, each unique form on your website should appear as a unique form in Leadin.

Leadin identifies forms based on the CSS selector of the form. This means that, if your form has a CSS ID of 'gform_7', this will appear in Leadin Forms as '#gform_7'. Once a form is created, you can rename the form to something more understandable to you and your team.

Leadin will show your forms in the sidebar of Leadin Contacts, as soon as it has captured the first submission on that form. If you have a Gravity Form on your website, for example, this form will not appear on your website until Leadin has picked up a submission on the form. Once one submission has taken place, then the form will exist in the Leadin Contacts sidebar where you can configure options like a connection to an email provider or rename the form.

name: Why does my contact have no page views?
post_body:
As soon as a visitor comes to your website, Leadin generates a brand new tracking cookie for them, and sets this cookie in their browser. Leadin logs all page views against this unique cookie and as soon as your visitor submits a form, Leadin will surface all this information into a contact timeline for you. More about contact tracking here.

Under some circumstances, a contact may not show any page views in their timeline for a few reasons. Since it is this browser cookie that enables Leadin to tie together all their page views over time, if the visitor decides to prevent cookies from being used in their browser, this would prevent Leadin (and other analytical tools, such as Google Analytics and HubSpot) from logging their page views. There are a number of ways an individual might achieve this, from settings in their browser, to browser extensions such as Ghostery.

Ultimately it is up to the individual if they do or do not want their page views to be logged by analytical tools like Leadin and Google Analytics.

name: How does Leadin Track Visitors?
post_body:
Leadin tracks every visitor that comes to your site using browser cookies. Every time a visitor lands on your website, Leadin will check for the presence of an existing tracking cookie. If a tracking cookie doesn't exist, Leadin spins up a unique browser cookie for that visitor and will log every page that person visitor moving forward.

Leadin will track the page view activity of each visitor anonymously even before she becomes a contact. For example, if a person visits your website three separate times before filling out a form, Leadin will still include the previous visits in the contact timeline provided all these visits occurred on the same browser.

Leadin cookies are set to never expire. Since Leadin uses a cookie to track visitors, if a visitor deletes her cookies, Leadin will think that person is a "new visitor" next time she visits your site, and assigns her a new tracking code. We do have logic that will merge her contact record with her prior history the next time she fills out a form with the same email though. If you're curious about how that works, checking the "Contact merging - by email address" section below.

Leadin automatically integrates with most contact forms on your site that contain an email address field. Any time an anonymous visitor fills out a form and an email address is present, Leadin will identify that visitor as a contact and generate a contact record for you inside your Leadin account.

Leadin does not allow you to view page view history for anonymous visitors right now. This is a feature we're evaluating for the future.

Sometimes a person will visit your website from two different browsers, like a mobile phone and a work computer. Since cookies can't be passed between two different browsers, Leadin assigns each "visitor" a different tracking code, when in reality it's actually the same person - let's call her Shirley.

No worries though, we have you covered. Let's say Shirley fills out a form on your website from her phone. Leadin will identify that anonymous visitor as Shirley, and keep track of her going forwad. A week later, Shirley is checking your awesome website while a work, and she fills out a different form with the same email address from her mobile session. At this point, Leadin realizes it's Shirley again, and will merge all her mobile history with her work history into the one contact timeline inside Leadin.

As outlined above, Leadin facilitates it's visitor tracking through cookies in the visitors web browser. Leadin will automatically merge multiple browser cookies together, if the submissions come from the same email address. The same is true for multiple submissions on a single browser, aka a single tracking cookie. Since cookies are unique to a browser, if John and Shirley share a single computer their submissions will be merged into a single contact record in Leadin due to there being the same tracking cookie present on for both submissions. Contact merging by cookie exists to ensure that, if Shirley submitted multiple forms on your website using a personal email address and a work email address, they are merged into a single record in Leadin since they are both Shirley. 

When testing submissions on your forms, it is important to be aware of this if you submit multiple tests from one single browser. If you are submitting forms with different email addresses, testing1@example.com and testing2@examile.com, these submissions will be merged into a single contact record in Leadin due to the presence of a common tracking cookie. The best way to test submissions, if you don't want them to be merged together, would be to test in the private browsing mode of your web browser. This ensures that you are given a new tracking cookie for each private browsing session, if you close your browser window between submissions.

Every time a visitor lands on your website, Leadin will check for the presence of an existing tracking cookie. If a tracking cookie doesn't exist, Leadin spins up a unique browser cookie for that visitor and will log every page that person visitor moving forward.

name: Frequently Asked Questions
post_body:
We've compiled a list of most frequently asked questions we've had from our users and listed them below.

  1. When you install the Leadin tracking code or activate the WordPress plugin (if you're on WordPress), Leadin will track each anonymous visitor to your site with a cookie.
  2. Once someone fills out any form on your site, Leadin will identify that person with their email address and generate a contact record for that individual.
  3. You’ll receive an email with a link to the new contact record with all of their visit history.

Leadin automatically integrates with your contact and comment forms that contain an email address field on your web site. There’s no setup required.

Provided your form is a static HTML form, wrapped in a HTML <form> tag and not contained inside an <iframe>, Leadin should be able to capture the submissions. 

Some common reasons why Leadin would not be able to capture submissions on forms:

  • Form not enclosed in <form> tags
  • Form contained inside an <iframe>
  • Form has JavaScript bound to form submit event or submit button click event
    • This is how Leadin captures submissions, and any other events can prevent Leadin from knowing when submissions occur
  • Form was introduced after the page completed loading
    • Leadin scans the page as soon as it loads and listens to submissions on forms that were present at that point

Learn more here.

There’s a few reasons why you might not be seeing the popup. If you close the popup, Leadin won’t show it to you again for a period of two weeks. We recommend trying to view your site in a Chrome ‘incognito window’. You can also use the “Preview Popup” button in your Leadin settings to view the popup even if you’ve closed it.

If it’s still not working, please confirm that Leadin is installed on your website. For the Leadin WordPress plugin, Leadin requires that your templates have both WordPress header and footer includes to work properly. We include code in those files to make the Leadin tracking and popups work.

From within Settings you can change the colour of the popup form elements under the setting 'Button color'. Beyond this there’s no built in ability to change the style of the popup form. You can apply any CSS styles you want to the plugin to make it look how you want. The container class is “.leadin-subscribe”. This CSS would need to be written inside your website's CSS file, since Leadin does not have any customisable CSS files.

Leadin sets a small number of cookies in a visitors browser to facilitate with identifying analytical tracking. For a full breakdown of each cookie, see here.

Right now, the Leadin application is available in English and the Leadin plugin is available in French, Spanish, Japanese, German and Brazilian Portuguese. We’re hoping to offer translations for the Leadin application soon.

Unfortunately, due to the way WooCommerce submits forms, Leadin is unable to provide tracking for those forms. However, if a visitor submits a supported form on your site, Leadin will be able to track them on WooCommerce product pages.

You betcha! Leadin should work just fine on multisite right out-of-the-box without requiring any additional setup.

The basic version of Leadin is completely free! We’re working on some additional features that we’ll charge for in the future, but right now everything is free.

name: What cookies does Leadin set in a visitor's browser?
post_body:
Leadin's tracking code sets the following cookies, when a user visits your site:

hubspotutk (previously __leadinutk)
This cookie stores a unique value that we use to identify each unique visitor. This cookie is passed to Leadin on form submission and used when deduplicating contacts. This cookie was previously known as li_hash and li_classic_hash in Leadin v3 and lower.
(Expires: 2 years)

leadin_popup
This cookie is used to store if a visitor has ignored or submitted the Leadin popup form. If they have, we don't show them the popup again until the cookie expires.
(Expires: 14 days)

utk (set on the domain js.leadin.com)
This cookie is only used to set the __leadinutk cookie when one does not already exist.
(Expires: 2 years)
meta_description: Leadin's tracking code sets the following cookies, when a user visits your site: __leadinutk, leadin_popup and utk (on the domain js.leadin.com).

name: How do I know what the CSS selector of my form is?
post_body:
You can find a form selector by right clicking on one of the input fields inside the form you want to target in Google Chrome (or your favourite browser) and going to Inspect Element.

This will show you the HTML source for your page and highlight the specific input. Look up the page for a <form> element. There should be some attributes on the form that either say "id='my-form-id'" or "class='my-form-class'".

  • HTML ID attributes are denoted by a "#" symbol, so you would look for "#my-form-id" in Leadin Forms.
  • HTML class attributes are denoted by a "." symbol, so you would look for ".my-form-class" in Leadin Forms.

If you don't want to nerd out and look at HTML source code, you can also install the SelectorGadget Chrome extension.

name: How do I clear my browser cookies if I am experiencing issues signing up?
post_body:
When installing Leadin via the WordPress plugin, Leadin enters a couple of rows into your WordPress database in order to connect your WordPress website to your newly created Leadin account.

Some WordPress servers may have trouble with this due to the number of cookies which are set for your own domain name. These range from your WordPress login cookie, plugin tracking cookies, Google Analytics (if installed) and many more. If the number of cookies set for your domain name goes beyond the limit your WordPress server can handle this will prevent Leadin from entering these Leadin account details into your WordPress database and you will not be able to sign up.

Luckily there is a way to delete your cookies, which should resolve this issue.

  • Deleting cookies in Google Chrome
  • Deleting cookies in Firefox
  • Deleting cookies in Internet Explorer
  • Deleting cookies in Safari
  • Deleting cookies in Opera

Once your cookies have been deleted you may need to log back into WordPress but you should now be able to successfully sign up for Leadin. If you are still experiencing issues, let us know.

name: How to install LeadOut
post_body:
We understand that not everyone can store their data in the cloud for different reasons. With that in mind, we have created an open source version of Leadin which you can continue to use for as long as you like, instead of upgrading to the newest cloud version of Leadin. This version of Leadin is known as LeadOut.

We offer this version as an option for those users who simply cannot store their data in the cloud and must keep their Leadin data in their local WordPress database. LeadOut will never prompt you to update to Leadin's cloud service.

IMPORTANT: We offer this version of Leadin as-is, meaning we do not provide support for this older version. If you would like to continue to receive updates and support please download the current cloud version of Leadin here and get all the newest features including easier syncing & email notification control, Include an image and custom thank-you message in the popup form. Also, redirect submissions on the form to a new page and so much more. Check out our user update for more.

Log into your WordPress admin and click the Plugins menu option

In order to install LeadOut we need to first remove Leadin. Click Deactivate below.

Next up we need to click Delete. Don't worry, your contacts and their history will not be deleted, just the old plugin. You will see all your original data in LeadOut once it has been installed.

Next, download a copy of LeadOut, here. You will need to click the "Download ZIP" button on the right/top. 

Now that you've downloaded LeadOut you'll need to navigate back to your Plugins in WordPress and install it. Go to Plugins > Add New

From the Add Plugins area, you'll want to click on the Upload Plugin button.

Next you'll want to locate the zip file you downloaded earlier of the LeadOut plugin by clicking Choose File

This will prompt a pop-up box to open where you can search your computer for the file. Once you find the file in your computer folders, click the zip file and then click Open.

Now you'll see the selected file in WordPress. Click the Install Now button to begin installation of LeadOut.

Once the installation of the LeadOut plugin is initiated, you'll be redirected to an install screen that should show you the steps taken to unpack and install the plugin. Once complete click Activate Plugin to continue with installing LeadOut.

Now you've successfully installed and activated LeadOut! You should see LeadOut appear now on your side menu in WordPress and all your previous Leadin data from version 3 of the WordPress plugin should be ready to use!

name: How to use the Leadin Dashboard
post_body:
Once you've installed Leadin on your website you have access to all its inbound marketing tools that will help you get to know your website visitors. This starts with your Dashboard, which gives you an overview of your contact activity.

The Dashboard runs on a rolling 30 day timeframe. So when you navigate to Dashboard to check on your Leadin activity, it will show you the last 30 days worth of activity from the time you are currently accessing this data.

At the top of the Dashboard you will see a graph of new contacts within the last 30 days. You will see multiple pieces of information in this part of the dashboard:

  1. How many new contacts your website has generated in the past 30 days
  2. A breakdown of how many new contacts your website has generated by day
  3. New contacts today
  4. Average new contacts per day (also represented by the dotted blue line)
  5. Best day ever! How many contacts you had on your best new contact day
  6. Total contacts from all-time

You'll also notice that if you hover your mouse over a specific date on this graph, it will show you the specific day and exactly the number of contacts you received on that day.

Below the graph of new contacts from the past 30 days, you'll see a section dedicated to new and returning contacts. You'll see a section for new contacts that you've received today and returning contacts today. In these sections, you'll see their contact info along with their original source and number of pageviews.

The last section of your Dashboard consists of your new contacts sources from the last 30 days. This will show you how your contacts have found your website. You'll see the source, the number of contacts that came to your website from that source, and then a visual graph of the number of new contacts from each source (quickly showing you which channels are working best for you and which you may want to work on). Let's go over each source quickly:

Direct Traffic: visitors that accessed your site through a direct URL - either by someone sending a direct link to your web page (without tracking parameters) or someone going into a browser and simply typing in your website URL.

Organic Search: visits from a non-paid search result from search engines like Google, Bing, and Yahoo.

Referrals: visits from an external site that links to your website directly.

Social Media: visits from a link that came from a social media website like Facebook or Twitter.

Email Marketing: visits from a link that came from an email marketing campaign (this is determined by an email URL tracking parameter).

Paid Search: visits from a paid search, like Google AdWords.

More information on the source categorisation can be found here.

You can look at this graph here and see that the direct traffic for this website is doing a stellar job of creating a new contacts, but there is certainly a huge opportunity to get this website some attention on social media. 

Currently in testing is a new section which breaks down the number of views and submissions your Leadin Popup form received in the last 30 days, and a calculation of the conversion rate based on these numbers. This data is automatically generated for you when the popup is added to your site.

name: Get to know Leadin
post_body:
Owning a website is a must these days, and if you own a website you know that getting leads from your website can be a trying task. How are you supposed to know what is attracting visitors to your site or stopping them from visiting again? It's important your business gives as much information as possible on your website but knowing what interests them and what doesn't can be key to getting their business.

This is where we hope we come in. Leadin is a tool that works with most sites to give you better tools to engage with and understand how people are interacting with your website. While WordPress is a great tool for content creation, Leadin tries to fill the gap for helping you gather and interpret visitor data on your site.

With Leadin you'll be able to answer two crucial questions:

  1. Who is visiting my site?
  2. What content are they viewing before and after becoming leads?

Your contacts database will show you all contacts that have converted on your site along with their original source type, visits, pageviews, and more. You can go into an individual contact to see a timeline of all of their activity, all the details you need to make your next move.

Forms in Leadin are dynamically generated based on the existing forms on your site. Leadin has the ability to capture submissions on most existing forms on your website so no need to change your current website. As soon as you install Leadin you are ready to start generating contacts and learning about the pages they've viewed and how they found your website. Learn more about how this feature works.

The Leadin plugin provides you with the ability to create a lead flow (pop up form) and add it to your website right from within Leadin. Lead flows can help prevent people from slipping through the cracks by targeting them based on their behaviour on your website, on specific pages or all pages. The popup also uses the contact data to intelligently know when to appear. More on that here.

Leadin features the ability to connect to 5 major email providers, MailChimp, Constant Contact, Campaign Monitor, GetResponse and AWeber. This connection allows you to push new contacts generated to the mailing list of your choice, find out how.

Leadin will give you a general statistical overview of the last 30 days of your contacts - it'll show you what days you obtained new contacts and even what traffic source drove them to your site. Simple and straightforward.

How are you supposed to know what is attracting visitors to your site or stopping them from visiting again? name: Why did Leadin flag my form submission?
post_body:
One of the core features of Leadin is it's ability to capture submissions on the existing, non-Leadin, forms on your website. For a detailed explanation of how this works, check out this article.

The Leadin form capture tool includes logic that allows it to intelligently identify if a form has any sensitive fields, for example a password field or a credit card field. Due to the sensitive nature of this information, and that Leadin stores form submissions in plain-text, Leadin will not capture this information on a form. 

Leadin achieves this check for sensitive information by scanning the form for field labels that suggest credit card information is present, such as credit card, card number, expiration, expiry, ccv, cvc, cvv, secure code, mastercard, american express and amex. In addition to this, Leadin checks for number fields on the form and uses a formula to identify if this number could possibly be a credit card.

Even though Leadin includes this logic to prevent sensitive information from being captured, the data that is captured is your responsibility. Should Leadin ever incorrectly capture sensitive information, please let us know. For more information, see our Privacy Policy.

For a detailed explanation of how this works, check out this article.\n\nThe Leadin form capture tool includes logic that allows it to intelligently identify if a form has any sensitive fields, for example a password field or a credit card field. Due to the sensitive nature of this information, and that Leadin stores form submissions in plain-text, Leadin will not capture this information on a form.

name: How do I rename a Form in Leadin?
post_body:
In Leadin, the forms on your site are automatically generated as Collected Forms in Leadin. You can find them all under Collected Forms in Leadin.

To rename a form, simply load that form and click the name of the form at the top of the table. Once the edits have been made, click 'enter' on your keyboard and the changes are saved.

name: How do I prevent Leadin from tracking WordPress users?
post_body:
If you're using the Leadin WordPress plugin we include the ability to prevent Leadin from tracking your page views and form submissions if you are logged into WordPress itself. 

To enable this setting head over to Settings inside the Leadin WordPress plugin and here you will find Contacts Tracking. This setting allows you to disable Leadin page view tracking and form submission tracking for logged in users in WordPress, including the standard user roles in WordPress and also any custom users roles.

In the above example Administrators and Editors will not be tracked by Leadin when logged into WordPress. 

IMPORTANT: This setting, when enabled, prevents Leadin from capturing form submissions when you are logged into WordPress. If you want to test Leadin's tracking of forms on your site it is important to either disable this setting or log out of WordPress when testing.
meta_description: If you're using the Leadin WordPress plugin we include the ability to prevent Leadin from tracking your page views and form submissions if you are logged into WordPress itself.

name: How do I add users to my Leadin account?
post_body:
Navigate to Settings under the Leadin Account Menu.

From here you will find the Users menu and the Add user button.

This will bring up the wizard to add a new user to your Leadin account, you must provide their email address, first name and last name.

The next step is to choose their permissions. You will notice two types of permissions, Account permissions and Leadin permissions. Account permissions allow you to manage users across all HubSpot products connected to a single Hub ID, for example Leadin and the HubSpot CRM. It is not currently possible to integrate Leadin and the HubSpot CRM together, but when this is possible the Account administrator will be able to manage users across all HubSpot products connected to your Hub ID. 

Finally choose whether or not this new user will receive a Welcome Email. The Welcome Email provides the new users with instructions to set their account password.

You can now manage your Users from within Leadin including changing their permissions, resetting their password or deleting the user.
meta_description: If you are a user of the Leadin WordPress plugin your Leadin account is accessible to all WordPress Administrators. For those using the Leadin Web App it is now possible to add additional users to your Leadin account by following these steps.

name: How do I edit my lead flow?
post_body:
Lead flows is a brand new tool from Leadin, it replaces the Popup Form tool and extends it's functionality and design to include a Callout/CTA step and an interactive editor.

To access Lead Flows, navigate to Leadin > Lead Flows (in the navigation, or Settings > Popup Form > Lead Flows in WordPress).

Lead flows are available in four different types:

Popup Box

Popup Box is the most attention-grabbing and best used to promote social channels, grow your email list, and provide the most valuable content you have.

Dropdown Banner

Dropdown Banner is best used to promote a timely offer (i.e. a sale, webinar), or grow your blog subscribers.

Slide-in Box Left/Right

Slide-in Box is best used to promote your content or grow blog subscribers.

The callout (or CTA) is an opportunity to grab your visitor's attention with a brief description of what you're offering via a title, description, image and theme colour.

In the callout step of the editor you can:

  1. Upload an image which is included on the callout and form step
  2. Set your callout text (the main header)
  3. Adjust the button text (also included in the form step)
  4. Set the theme colour which will be included throughout the lead flow

You will see a live update of the changes you make on the right-hand side of the editor.

From within the form step you can add some additional fields to the form, change the language of the fields and add a body to elaborate on the value you are providing with your lead flow.

Language allows you to change the language of the non-editable parts of the popup, including the form field labels. Currently it is possible to translate these parts of the form to French, Spanish, Japanese, German and Brazilian Portuguese. Looking for a language that's not listed? Let us know.

The body text will also be included in the callout step of your lead flow.

Lastly, create a thank you message that your visitor will see after submitting your form. You can link your visitor to additonal resources/downloads and include some lightly formatted text.

From within options you can adjust the location of your leaf dlow, along with the triggers that will cause it to appear for your user and more.

First up you can adjust the internal name for your lead flow or unpublish it. The name will appear in the timeline for your contacts and in internal email notifications.

Next up, configure which pages you'd like your lead flow to appear on (or all pages). The 'exact match URL' option in Leadin supports a wildcard option, for example "http://www.website.com/blog/*" (note the asterisk at the end) if you'd like it to appear on all pages on your blog.

Following location, you can choose the user interaction that will trigger the lead flow. Page scroll will trigger the moment your visitor scrolls 50% down your page. Elapsed time simply triggers the moment X seconds have past. Exit intent allows you to trigger the lead flow when the visitor's mouse exits the their browser window (for example, when they're about to close the browser tab). Last up, you can set a time delay (minimum 7 seconds). Options differ between different lead flow types. 

Don't want this lead flow to appear on mobile? Disable it using the next option. Lead flows are fully mobile optimised, so in most circumstances it's definitely recommended to include your lead flow on mobile.

Lastly, you can enable/disable internal email notifications for new submissions on this lead flow.

You can connect Leadin to an email provider (more on that here). If you have Leadin connected to a provider you can select which lists new contacts who submit this lead flow will be pushed into. 

The lead flows editor provides an interactive preview where you can test each stage of your lead flow and see it in action. This preview offers the ability to view on desktop, tablet and mobile.

Want to unpublish your lead flow?

Head into options and you'll find an Unpublish option at the top. You can also unpublish right from the Lead Flows Dashboard.
meta_description: Configure your Leadin Flow in our brand new editor

name: The Lead Flows Dashboard
post_body:
When clicking on Lead Flows in your Leadin navigation you will be brought to your Lead Flows Dashboard. From here you can create new lead flows in your account (more than one) and see some high-level data and manage each lead flow you've created.

Create new lead flows

You can now create multiple lead flows within Leadin through the new Lead Flows Dashboard by clicking 'Create new' in the top-right of the page. This will allow you to create lead flows for different pages and purposes. 

Activate and Deactivate your lead flows

You can now quickly activate and deactivate a lead flow right from the Lead Flows Dashboard through the toggles beside each one. 

Lead flow analytics

The Lead Flows Dashboard provides an overview of the performance of your lead flows by providing the views, contacts and conversion rate of each one. The timeline for this data is provided since the lead flow was created. 

Have a new feature or update you'd like to see for the Lead Flows Dashboard? Let us know on our Ideas Forum here.
meta_description: When clicking on Lead Flows in your Leadin navigation you will be brought to your Lead Flows Dashboard. From here you can create new lead flows in your account (more than one) and see some high-level data and manage each lead flow you've created.

name: How do I add Leadin to my HubSpot account?
post_body:
Leadin is now available as a free add-on for HubSpot Marketing and HubSpot CRM. To add Leadin to your HubSpot account, follow these steps.

Note: This is an early release of the add-on, features may be partially incomplete and you may find some rough edges but for the most part, you should not experience any issues.

Add Leadin to HubSpot

Please note that you will need to be an Account Administrator to activate Leadin on your account.

  • Navigate to your HubSpot Marketing or HubSpot CRM portal.

  • Once in your Settings, select Products & Add-Ons

  • Locate the Leadin section to activate Leadin on your HubSpot portal.

What's next?

Once Leadin is installed on your HubSpot portal, if you're using Leadin with HubSpot Marketing, you'll find the Lead Flows tool under Content in your existing navigation rather than seeing a completely separate navigation. As seen here: 

If you're using Leadin with HubSpot Sales, you'll find a separate navigation under the top right dropdown in your account, as seen here: 

Video walkthrough of the Leadin add-on

{{ script_embed('wistia', '9v6ri6m9j0', 'undefined', 'responsive') }}

The Leadin add-on provides a way to add the Leadin features to HubSpot Marketing and HubSpot CRM. This is not an integration between an existing Leadin portal and a HubSpot portal, it is a way to add Leadin's functionality to your HubSpot account.

Dashboard

The Leadin add-on does not include the native Leadin Dashboard as a dashboard is provided in HubSpot. We are working to introduce the lead generation reports to the HubSpot Dashboard soon.

Contacts

The Leadin add-on does not include a Contacts screen as all leads generated via lead flows are automaicallly created in your core HubSpot contacts database.

List and workflows in HubSpot Marketing

You can segment contacts who submit your lead flows inside HubSpot by using the normal Form Submission segmentation option. You will find each lead flow you create right inside the form submission dropdown.

Segmentation in HubSpot Sales

 At the moment it is not possible to segment in HubSpot Sales based on submissions on certain lead flows or collected forms. This is something that we are working on and should be possible soon.

Tracking code/plugin

If you are using HubSpot Marketing, Leadin is automatically included on your website via your existing HubSpot tracking code. If you are using HubSpot CRM, Leadin will be included on your site via the HubSpot tracking code if you have it installed. If you do not have it installed you can follow these steps in Leadin to install: Install Leadin Tracking Code or if you are using WordPress, install the HubSpot Tracking Code plugin and provide your HubSpot Hub ID.

Need help?

To get help with Leadin, please use the 'Help' option in the bottom-right of each screen in Leadin or here.

name: How do I install Leadin?
post_body:
Leadin has two installation options depending on your Content Management System (CMS). If you are using WordPress.org for your website, you can install the Leadin WordPress plugin on your website and sign up for a new account if you don't have one, or connect the plugin to an existing Leadin account if you have already signed up. 

If you are using any other CMS, you can install Leadin via the tracking code provided in Settings.

Install Leadin on WordPress.org

To install Leadin on your WordPress website, follow these steps: Install Leadin WordPress plugin

If you already have a Leadin account, you can connect the WordPress plugin to this account via your Leadin token which you will find in Settings > Installation. For more information see this guide.

Install Leadin on any other Content Management System

Leadin can also be installed on any CMS which allows a JavaScript snippet to be added to the website. We have a series of installation guides for most CMSs here but if we do not have a guide for your CMS let us know.
meta_description: Leadin has two installation options depending on your Content Management System (CMS). If you are using WordPress.org we have a plugin, for all other CMSs we provide an embed code.

name: Error running two Leadin tracking codes
post_body:
Due to how Leadin is built and runs on your website, it is not possible to install more than one Leadin tracking code on a single website. In the event that there are two installed at one, the first one to load will be the one that remains active and any subsequent Leadin tracking codes will not initialise.

To identify what you have installed on your website, it is best to use your browsers in-built development tools. In Chrome, for example, you can right click on any part of your website and click "Inspect". This will bring up Chrome's Developer Tools on the 'Elements' tab. In here you can search for 'js.leadin.com' which will show you all the Leadin tracking codes installed on the website right now. Identify which you do no use and uninstall it to ensure that Leadin works correctly.
meta_description: Due to how Leadin is built and runs on your website, it is not possible to install more than one Leadin tracking code on a single website.

name: How do I delete my Leadin account?
post_body:
To delete your Leadin account, follow these steps:

  • Navigate to Settings in Leadin.
  • Within Settings, select Configuration. 
  • Scroll to the Delete your Leadin account section and click the red Delete Leadin button.

Finally, you will be prompted to enter your HubID in order to confirm you would like to permanently delete the Leadin portal.

Please note: This is not something that can be undone, please be sure that you want to delete your account and have exported your data before hand.
meta_description: You can delete your Leadin account from within Settings > Configuration > Delete
